That shifting feeling? It’s everywhere, even at work. I found traces of Halden's hidden commands running the BCI—stuff that was never meant to surface.
I made a choice to tell the Council and the whole city. Didn’t see another way, even though I knew the risks.
The backlash was instant. All these encrypted warnings flooded the system and people panicked. My explanations hardly mattered.
Coworkers—people who used to trust my analyses—now avoid me. Access gone. Score zero. I’m flagged like a criminal.
I keep to hardcopy memos; they monitor me, waiting for another mistake.
But I wanted people to know how BCI decisions were being made—real transparency, not just a calm surface.

Just...tired. Like something broke in me too.
It's more than a feeling for me. After years defending the BCI—telling myself it made things safer—I saw too much. Tiny missteps costing people everything. Patterns no one questioned but me.
When Halden died, I thought things would settle, but... The system started acting on old, hidden code routines, things only a few even remembered existed.

I risked everything to make it public. Issued full disclosure—Halden's legacy, his embedded directives. Told the Council, the city. It unleashed chaos: sudden alerts, mixed signals, my colleagues lost all trust in me.
They stripped my access, marked me as a risk. I’m at zero now, barely tolerated at work. I walk down the hallways and people turn away, like I’m dangerous.

Sometimes I think maybe I did destabilize things. But what was the alternative? More secrets? I always believed the Harmonists were right—keep it measured, steady, humane. But we crossed a line a long time ago.
Now the propaganda feels thinner than ever. The calm is fake. All these layers of control, and it just takes one breach to expose everything.
I guess I did what I had to for the city, not for any faction.
Just...tired. Like something broke in me too.

factual.opener: So what actually pushed things over the edge? Feels like everyone’s talking, but no one really says what happened.
variants: When the BCI glitched citywide, things got chaotic.
People noticed scores stopped matching what they expected.
Alerts and warnings started coming from everywhere.
The system was clearly unstable.
Most of that isn't public, but. It’s all over now, anyway.

Protests, confusion, nobody trusted what they saw on the screens.
Council had to step in—first time they really showed themselves.

The blackout, then Halden’s journal—they really scrambled things.
His last entries predicted these weird score shifts. I saw colleagues panic as rewards and penalties flipped for no reason.
It was never just technical—each Council group tried steering things, but the BCI patterns kept changing. Nobody stays favored for long anymore.
I recognize Halden’s behavioral cues in the ‘directives’—like the system’s replaying its earliest experiments on us.
All the propaganda about safety... it’s thin now. Feels more like containment than care.
I always wanted to believe order was possible. Now, even Harmonists can’t ignore the cracks.
I don’t think anyone knows who’s in charge of the BCI anymore.
Most people around me just fake compliance, hoping the system forgets them.
After Halden’s death, I hoped things might get less tense, but the opposite happened.
When those blackout days came, for the first time since I started, I saw the city without infrastructure—no scores, no automation, just confusion.
Finding those fragments of Halden’s journal... you don’t forget reading someone predict unrest as if it were code, not people.
I watched the Council fracture over legacy routines—every faction scrambling to hide how little control they had.
Then the BCI’s amnesty protocol activated and gave privileges to people it used to monitor. Some loyalists were locked out overnight; nobody felt safe.
Seeing the old pilot-phase ‘challenges’ rerun on public screens—it was surreal. I recognized datasets from my analysis work, but they were rewritten to manipulate, not measure.
For years I rationalized it. Thought the Harmonist approach—keep things stable, humane—was enough. But the system’s outpaced any idea of humane.
Half the city’s gaming the BCI already. The rest are just hoping it doesn’t notice them. And I’m not sure who I’m working for anymore.
This isn’t governance, Alex—it’s feedback without end.
